title: Before 1 January 2021, will Ali Khamenei cease to be the supreme leader of Iran and/or Hassan Rouhani cease to be the president of Iran?
possible_answers: Yes, only Ali Khamenei will cease to be supreme leader
Yes, only Hassan Rouhani will cease to be president
Yes, both Ali Khamenei and Hassan Rouhani will cease to hold their respective positions, with neither replacing the other
Yes, both Ali Khamenei and Hassan Rouhani will cease to hold their respective positions, with at least one replacing the other

Khamenei cease (-13) Reasoning: The regime denied that this was in the works today and there has been no corroborating reporting. If it is happening, I doubt it is happening before January.

1-Mehdi Fazaeli, known for his closeness to Iranian Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, denied the allegations that Khamenei died. It was 8 hours ago.
2-https://twitter.com/MohamadAhwaze/status/1335938674203176960
I will monitor the reporting. If other outlets report that Khameni is stepping down, then I will adjust.

In addition, it is unclear if the succession will be permanent, as it goes against the constitution's rules regarding appointing a new supreme leader.
According to Article 111 of Iran's constitution, the supreme leader's successor is to be chosen by the Assembly of Experts, which currently consists of 88 ayatollahs. In the interim, the country would be administered by a provisional leadership council, which would consist of Iran's president, chief justice and a member of the guardian council.
However, according to articles from the prestigious Washington Institute for Near East Policy think tank, it may not be as simple as that, with outside pressure such as from the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps likely wanting a role in the process, due to the military body's influence on the Assembly of Experts.
https://www.jpost.com/middle-east/iran-supreme-leader-khamenei-hands-power-to-son-due-to-health-report-651268
“Unconfirmed reports” according to twitter. Right maybe half the time?
Nobody else has picked up the Newsweek story.  Also, not clear whether turning over powers, perhaps temporarily, is the same as ceasing to hold office.  Coming up from 0 to 1 because why not?
Whoa, I thought this one was done, but Khamenei may not make it to the end of the year. https://www.newsweek.com/fakhrizadeh-iran-1552586

Unconfirmed reports + "transferred" instead of "ceased to be" + not seeing mention of it in other news media means that I'm only moving a little bit. But I could imagine this changing in the following days.

Rouhani has been publicly allowed to condemn new US sanctions on Iran.

Rouhani's position was weakened with the new parliament being strongly conservative, but the political groupings now seem to have closed ranks.[1] Poverty is still wide spread and might lay the ground work for social protests, but the regime has managed to handle those before. Khamenei is more difficult to move than a deep rooted oak. He is not going anywhere, unless he dies. His only publicly known health issue is the prostate surgery he underwent in 2014. This is nothing major and would not pose a risk. I still leave a 2% in case he does have something that the regime keeps a secret, and this causes his death. But really, I don't expect it.
Rouhani is an elected president, and as one, he is always in risk of being challenged, asked to step down, or simply deposed. I also don't expect this to happen right now (and until end of 2020) but leave a 3% chance.
Further strengthening my position as we get closer to the closing date.

I will most likely regret my previous prediction. While I still believe the situation in Iran is unstable with a collapsing economy and huge social protests just waiting to break out[1, 2, 3], overthrowing of political regimes is rare.  Only Ali Khamenei will cease to be supreme leader: - 1

Iran has contained the virus relatively better than other governments as of July 2020, so is no longer a negative outlier, as it looked at the beginning of the outbreak in March 2020. US and other countries’ negative responses have taken over the global news, which relatively decreases the pressure on Iran’s government. This puts Rouhani out of immediate risk of early elections. The Ayatollah is deemed as an even more stable figure in Iran’s politics, therefore I assign 0% to his replacement. His health looks good and literally that would be the only reason for his replacement other than war or other external occupation. I leave a 10% room for early elections that could see Rouhani replaced.

With the coronavirus there is no much appetite for leadership change at the moment.  The mysterious blasts in Iran over recent weeks may manifest into something more serious and the impact of coronavirus will eventually have an impact.  But the probability of change seems quite low at the moment.  Of course there is still risk of illness, but both leaders are likely to be staying well protected.

Great analysis: "For two months, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the ultimate authority in Iran, has left Iran’s armed forces in charge of leading the country’s efforts against the covid-19 pandemic. The militarization of Iran’s public health efforts demonstrates how Khamenei and his allies have shrewdly used the outbreak to sideline the government of President Hassan Rouhani and increase their grip over the country’s population ... Iran’s leadership initially minimized the contagion’s risks and severity to avoid jeopardizing voter turnout during the country’s parliamentary elections, and Khamenei’s surrogates refused to restrict access to high-traffic religious shrines ... According to Iran’s constitution, the supreme leader has a lifetime appointment as the highest political and religious power in the land, controlling the armed forces and the security apparatus, and sitting above the president, who serves a four-year term, and the Majlis, having the ability to quash policies not in line with the ideological goals of the theocracy." https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/2020/05/27/irans-strategy-fighting-covid-19-could-backfire/

I start with the view that given a generic year the odds that either would lose office for exterior reasons are fairly low (1% for each). Then I add 1% for the odds that either get sick and die from Corona (1%). Then I consider political risks induced from sanction, Corona, and regional conflict (6%) and add another 10% due to the ambiguity of being 9 months out. The probability that each is removed is 4% but in the event that Khamenei is removed, there is a small chance that Rouhani replaces him.  NOTE: I mate need to go back and think through that all. I can't see either of them being overthrown by the people, considering their history of being in power over many protests. Out of the 2, the president is more susceptible to being ousted. However the supreme leader is older and is more susceptible to sickness. Chance of supreme leader dying: 8%. If he dies, I think there's a fairly high (75%) chance that the president will take over. - splitting 2% he dies without takeover, 6% he dies and is taken over by president. Chance of president dying: 3%.  Chance of both dying: 3%*8% = ~1%. Adding 2% to above predictions due to chance of them being ousted. Adding additional 2% to president's chances of being ousted. +3% all round due to uncertainty. I could see food shortages being a problem.  Totalling all the above up, I'm left with 70% "No".
Following @Jayce but with a little adjustment for direct COVI-19 risk to their deaths which I think is higher than in his estimate.

Just enjoyed a deep dive into this question. Being 80 years old, and at the helm of vast political power, I gave Khamenei's chances of ceasing to be supreme leader that of a standard 80 year old man: 1/15; rounded down for the financial resources at his disposal to maintain survival i.e. money 6%
Then due to extraordinary circumstances (possible cancer, assassination, stepping down, political overthrow) I gave a generous additional 3% The chances of Rouhani becoming supreme leader appear to be possible but incumbent upon the previous rationale, so both "Yes, both..." categories fall beneath the Khamenei question.
https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/supreme-leader-transform-iran-180119150403602.html The "Rouhani as president" question is a tricky one. No matter how dire the circumstances, this would come from within the government. A larger uprising is likely weakened by a populous fighting and fearful of COVID-19; yet again, this outrage may spur change. Chances of natural death 3%, +1% for unnatural death, and a generous +5% for known unknowns (e.g. internal uprising, pressure to step down, etc.) In fact, for good measure and owing for chaos +1% to all "yes" categories, just as an insurance buffer. So, until news develops, we/I sit squarely at mostly "no."
Although as we know, a lot can (and will) change in a year.

Because of the tightening of US sanctions, they have a strong argument for retaining their positions to fight the common enemy.

Thanks to Trump's decision to withdraw from the nuclear agreement, and recent tensions between the US and Iran,  the hardliners are in control. They are very unlikely to turf out either Khamenei or Rhouhani.

Adjusting for the fact that 1) Khamenei is a religious leader, so less likely to be replaced, and 2) Khamenei aligned with the military, ordering tougher policies which are appears to be perceived by people (at least in EU countries) as doing "everything possible to stop deaths".

Already in the midst of the COVID-19 outbreak,  Iranian parliamentary elections showed limited trust in Rouhani's leadership, with hardline ministers gathering strength (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-51570725). Hardliners broadly support the Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei. Yet, President Hassan Rouhani's government has been widely criticized for responding appropriately to the COVID-19 emergency (https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/israeli-government-warns-fatalities-virus-numbers-rise-69658922). Signalling lack of faith in the Rouhani government, Khamenei ordered the military to take charge of the situation. Rouhani refused to accept the change, and a standoff has ensued, with the military outright ignoring his orders (https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/17/world/middleeast/coronavirus-iran-rouhani.html). From English sources, most analysts blame Rouhani and rarely if ever mention Khamenei.  The only chance I see of Khamenei ceasing to be the supreme leader is if he was to contract the virus.

"Iran has one of the world’s worst outbreaks...An extraordinary burst of contradictory messages in recent days has angered many of the country’s 80 million citizens, already stressed by severe American economic sanctions, unemployment and mistrust of their leaders...In phone interviews and texts, supporters and opponents of President Hassan Rouhani’s government heavily criticized what they called its poor judgment, incompetence and failure to comprehend the severity of the crisis...Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s paramount leader, issued a written order last Thursday asking Maj. Gen. Mohammad Bagheri, the commander-in-chief of the Joint Armed Forces — an umbrella for the army, the Revolutionary Guards and security forces — to take charge. While he told the military to work with the civilian government, Mr. Khamenei effectively authorized it to sideline Mr. Rouhani’s government if needed..Mr. Rouhani appeared to have dissuaded the military from imposing strict rules. But local authorities defied him, independently closing provinces and several cities...Mr. Rouhani has been mocked for being mostly absent from public view and downplaying the threat." https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/17/world/middleeast/coronavirus-iran-rouhani.html

Increase in the status quo due to time

Iran is at an interesting juncture where protests against the regime have been picking pace for the last 6-12 months (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/01/world/middleeast/iran-protests-deaths.html). The aftermath of Covid-19 will only intensify the anger against the regime and will undermine the political class' legitimacy. There is a high chance that the supreme leader does not go, but the political leadership will change and the president could be a scapegoat.

Political regimes seem remarkably stable to pandemics. Even during the Black Death, the political structure of Europe did not change much. Moreover, in order to overthrow regimes there needs to be popular uprisings, which understandably people are unwilling to do during a pandemic. The only pathways in which the leaders fall is if they contract the coronavirus. But even then, they will be probably get access to the best medical care and will probably pull through.

Iran supreme leader and president  Things to consider for the outside view
- how often a supreme leader changes 
- Life expectancy 
- The length of time till the question ends 
- How could a SL change happen without death.  - how often a president changes, last 5 presidents have lasted 8 years. 
- Life expectancy (he is 71) life expectancy for a male is 75
- Elections, he won a first round majority of 57%, healthy lead. Next election due in 2021. Majority increased from 2013 Mortality (Outside)
The first thing to focus on is the age of both men. The supreme leader (SL), is 80 and the President (P) is 71. The life expectancy for Iranian men is 75. The age of death of the previous SL and P averages at 81, which is significant because they have better access to health care than the general population. Which if regressed to the mean, this gives a life expectancy of 78.  According to research, 2/3 of 70 year old men make it to their 80th birthday. Meaning 33% die. Divide that by the 10 year period gives you the chance of dying in 12 months. 3.3% An 80 year old man has only 1/5 chance of making 90. 80% chance he won’t, / the 10 year period. 8% chance he dies in the next year. 
There is also therefore a 1% chance they both die.  Regime (outside) 
Since the shah was defeated in 79, there has only been 2 SL. The current SL took the role from presidency, so we can assume that if the SL dies from natural causes, the P has a good chance of becoming SL. There is roughly a 5% chance the SL dies and the P does not. So let’s assume a 2% chance the P could be the SL.  Presidency (outside) 
Presidential elections in Iran happen every 4 years. Since 1981, there has been no early elections. The next elections are due in 2021. If early elections were called. The P has a healthy lead at 57% in round 1 (2017). 1% chance this happens.  Regime change (outside). 
How would a SL change? Only the US would have the capability, via direct or indirect action, to force a coup. Since the 90’s. The US have been involved in 11 coup attempts. 4 of which were successful is changing leadership. 11 in 30 years is 36% x 34% success rate. Roughly 10% chance. Lower that a little as the attempted US coups took place all over the world. 6% is about right.  (Inside)
The most important factor from the outside is the current Covid 19 pandemic. 
As both men are in the at risk categories.  British experts say 80% of people will get the virus. And mortality rates for a 80 year old is 14%. 70 = 8%.  So the chance of dying from Covid 19. 80% x 14 % = 11% (SL)
80% x 8% = 6.4% (P)  Let’s assume because they have access to better healthcare and more assurances will be taken. -3% from both. 
SL 8% 
P 4%  Other factors to consider - 
Internal uprisings - low chance considering the power the gov have. 1%  Economic decrease due to Covid - little relevance to the above considered as regime change at SL level will only occur through death, resignation, or coup/military. However it does increase tensions. +1%.  I will also increase both to leave by 5% as I just have a feeling of increased tension.

With the virus going around, you're probably not going to get as many people congregating in large groups. Preventing large groups meeting is a textbook authoritarian tactic for preventing conspiracy to overthrow a leader. The virus also gives an excuse for extraordinary measures to be taken under the guise of public health. The drop in oil prices does put a strain on finances, and thus opens an opportunity for change, though the next leader would not have any easier of a time paying off his inner circle. So, a popular uprising seems very unlikely, but an internal coup could be possible, at least as an outside chance which I will put at 1 in 25, split evenly among all yes's. If Khamenei dies, I'll give a 50% chance to Rouhani succeeding him.
